title: 2025 Kings County DA Email Retention Policies

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: 2025 Kings County DA Email Retention Policies
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records sufficient to show the Kings County District Attorney's Office general retention schedule of records, the records inventory worksheet, and documentation describing policies and practices followed by the District Attorney's office on performing email searches and record redaction. These documents include, but are not limited to:

1. The District Attorney's Office general retention period for records, including but not limited to emails, 
2. The District Attorney's Office current policies and guidelines related to records management, retention, and disposition
3. The current, complete Master Records Schedule for the District Attorney's Office, or equivalent master index of records
4. The most recent version of California State form STD. 70 (Records Inventory Worksheet) for the District Attorney's Office, or equivalent records
5. The current Department Retention File plan for the District Attorney's Office, or equivalent records, such as the Departmental Records Retention Schedule or other relevant documents
6. Records that describe how the DA's office performs email searches when searching for public records. These records may include, but are not limited to, technical manuals or vendor documentation describing the kinds of keyword searches can be performed, especially advanced or "boolean" searches
7. Records which describe the technical limitations of the aforementioned system(s) for searching emails when it comes to searching and exporting results, such as the maximum number of records that can be exported for a single search and the maximum file size that can be exported for a single search
8. Records describing the processes and tools used by the DA's office to redact sensitive information before returning records. This request does not cover policy documents explaining the legal bases for redacting; only the records that explain HOW redaction is carried out.

For numbered items 7, 8, and 9, please include, without limitation, technical manuals, vendor documentation, trainings, FAQs, and tutorials.

For reference, I have attached responses from the Los Angeles County District Attorney, San Francisco County District Attorney, and Alpine County District Attorney to California Public Records Act requests for similar documents. These include the following documents listed below:

1. Los Angeles District Attorney Office Departmental Records Retention Schedule (DRRS), file name: "los_angeles_county_dao_drrs.pdf"
2. San Francisco District Attorney's Office Record Retention and Destruction Policy, file name: "san_francisco_dao_record_retention_policy.pdf"
3. Alpine County District Attorney's Office correspondence with MuckRock News on March 9, 2023 responding to Public Records Act request, file name: "03_09_2023_alpine_county_dao_request_response.pdf"

Please note that the California Public Records Act allows a member of the public to request records by describing their content, rather than asking for specific documents by name; an agency that receives such a request must “search for records based on criteria set forth in the search request.” CFAC, 67 Cal. App. 4th at 165-66.

Please let me know should there be any clarification or assistance I can provide to in order to "make a focused and effective request that reasonably describes an identifiable record or records" (Gov. Code §7922.600).

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

John Doe

title: LAKE WASHINGTON SCHOOL DISTRICT – (2025) Request for a complete electronic copy of all Public Records Requests received by the District including the District Responses for the year 2025

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: LAKE WASHINGTON SCHOOL DISTRICT – (2025) Request for a complete electronic copy of all Public Records Requests received by the District including the District Responses for the year 2025
communications.communication:
08-14-2025

LAKE WASHINGTON SCHOOL DISTRICT – (2025) Request for a complete electronic copy of all Public Records Requests received by the District including the District Responses for the year 2025

Via email: PublicRecordsRequest@lwsd.org

To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act [RCW 42.56] I hereby request the following records:

1. I request a complete electronic copy of all Public Records Requests received by your agency in the year 2025 and a complete electronic copy of your agency's Responses to each of these Public Records Requests for the year 2025.

RECORDS INSTALLMENTS - ORDER OF PRODUCTION

If production of responsive records will be completed in multiple installments, please begin by producing records in REVERSE CHRONOLOGICAL FORMAT BY DATE. The most recent public records should be produced first and the oldest records produced last by date.

DEFINITION OF RECORDS AND WRITINGS

RECORDS AND WRITINGS as defined by RCW 42.56.010(4): any handwriting, typewriting, printing, photostating, photographing, and every other means of recording any form of communication or representation including, but not limited to, letters, words, pictures, sounds, or symbols, or combination thereof, and all papers, maps, magnetic or paper tapes, photographic films and prints, motion picture, film and video recordings, magnetic or punched cards, discs, drums, diskettes, sound recordings, and other documents including existing data compilations from which information may be obtained or translated.

NATIVE ELECTRONIC FORMAT

Please provide all identified public records in their NATIVE electronic format. Please provide all electronic records in the fewest number of individual files as per native format or use free .zip or digital compression in each installment for the fewest number of total records and the most economical calculation of any applicable public records fees.

USE OF PORTAL NOT MANDATORY - DIRECTING REQUESTORS TO THIRD-PARTY LINKS VIOLATES ACCESS RIGHTS

Third-party portals often require creating an account or logging in, restrict downloads or viewing times, and remove or disable links after a short period of time.

These restrictions unlawfully condition access to public records and are inconsistent with RCW 42.56.080 and RCW 42.56.550.

Because of this, Washington State Law is clear that the use of 3rd party “portals” (Such as GOVQA.com) for  public records requests is optional for the requestor. Respectfully I decline. Please provide all records electronically via direct email attachment to this email address.

Please do not register this requestor for, nor direct this requestor to the use of any 3rd party commercial portal including but not limited to FOIAOnline, GovQA, NextRequest, FOIAExpress, JustFOIA FOIADirect, WebForm, or any other online service other than a direct NO PASSWORD REQUIRED, NO REGISTRATION REQUIRED, internet cloud-based download link, or electronic email.

Do not send any portion of this public records request to any 3rd party for-profit corporation such as GOVQA, a Grannicus Corporation or NEXT-REQUEST.

Do not register this request with any for profit portal or 3rd party organization such as GOVQA, a Grannicus Corporation, or NEXT-REQUEST.

PUBLIC RECORDS REQUESTS SUBMITTED VIA EMAIL

RCW 42.56.080 - Identifiable records—Facilities for copying—Availability of public records.

"...Agencies shall honor requests received in person during an agency's normal office hours, or by mail or email, for identifiable public records unless exempted by provisions of this chapter. No official format is required for making a records request; however, agencies may recommend that requestors submit requests using an agency provided form or web page."

This public records request is being made via email. This public records request will be honored and fulfilled by your agency via email as requested or relief will be sought per statute.

FEES

In the event that there are fees, please inform us of the total charges in advance of fulfilling the request in strict compliance with all provisions of the Washington State Public Records Act.

EXEMPTION LOGS

Please ensure all redactions or exemptions claimed by your agency in the production of responsive records are accompanied by a complete and detailed exemption log noting the valid legal reason for each exemption at each redaction location in the record produced, as well as the specific number of pages if any that your agency redacts or withholds in their entirety. Each redaction should be noted by footnote or by a clear reference to the specific justification for that redaction, and only the minimal exempt portion of any record may be withheld.

COMMERCIAL PURPOSE DECLARATION

The Washington State Public Records Act prohibits the disclosure of “lists of individuals” for a commercial purpose (RCW 42.56.070(8)). I declare this public records request is not being made for any commercial purpose whatsoever. Also, this public records request is not being made for a "list of individuals." This declaration satisfies all requirements of RCW 42.56 regarding prohibitions on lists and commercial purposes. No additional commercial purpose declaration will be completed for this public records request.

PRESERVATION OF PUBLIC RECORDS *** ANTICIPATE LITIGATION ***

WAC 44-14-03005 RETENTION OF PUBLIC RECORDS

The lawful destruction of public records is governed by retention schedules. The unlawful destruction of public records can be a crime. RCW 40.16.010 and 40.16.020. An agency is prohibited from destroying a public record, even if it is about to be lawfully destroyed under a retention schedule, if a public records request has been made for that record. RCW 42.56.100. Additional retention requirements might apply if the records may be relevant to actual or anticipated litigation. The agency is required to retain the record until the record request has been resolved.

Note: An agency can be found to violate the Public Records Act and be subject to the attorneys' fees and penalty provision if it prematurely destroys a requested record after a request is made. See Yacobellis v. City of Bellingham, 55 Wn. App. 706, 780 P.2d 272 (1989). However, it is not a violation of the Public Records Act if a record is destroyed prior to an agency's receipt of a public records request for that record. Bldg. Indus. Ass'n of Wash. v. McCarthy, 152 Wn. App. 720, 218 P.3d 196 (2009); West v. Dep't of Nat. Res., 163 Wn. App. 238, 258 P.3d 78 (2011). The Public Records Act (chapter 42.56 RCW) and the records retention statutes (chapter 40.14 RCW) are two different laws.

COMMUNICATION VIA EMAIL

Please send all requests for clarification, status updates, and production of responsive electronic documents via direct email reply.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. We look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Good Luck.

title: Lake Washington School District - JUSTFOIA Software Purchase, Installation, Configuration, Integration, Administration (08/2025)

communications.communication:
08-13-2025

via email to PublicRecordsRequest@lwsd.org

Lake Washington School District - JUSTFOIA Software Purchase, Installation, Configuration, Integration, Administration (08/2025)

PUBLIC RECORDS REQUEST RCW 42.56

To whom it may concern,

I request the following identifiable public records to be produced in the following order of production, newest to oldest by year:

Pursuant to Washington’s Public Records Act (PRA), RCW 42.56, I request inspection and electronic copies of all records and writings (as those terms are defined in RCW 42.56.010) relating to Lake Washington School District’s purchase, installation, configuration, integration, administration, and use of the JustFOIA public records software platform (a CivicPlus company), including any related CivicPlus components or services.

Timeframe

Please search from January 1, 2015 to the present, or the earliest date responsive records exist, whichever is broader.

Definitions, scope, and preservation

“Records” and “writings” include all formats: emails, texts/iMessages, chats (Teams/Slack/Google Chat), letters, notes, photos, spreadsheets, databases, calendars, audio/video, PDFs, logs, dashboards, data exports, screen captures, configuration files, source or script files, API payloads, and associated metadata (system, header, and audit metadata). See RCW 42.56.010; O’Neill v. City of Shoreline (metadata is a public record).

Personal accounts/devices used for public business are in scope (e.g., texts or emails about JustFOIA). See Nissen v. Pierce County.

Please immediately preserve potentially responsive ESI in all repositories (email, Teams/Slack, SharePoint/OneDrive/Google Drive, file servers, ticketing, finance/procurement, security tools, and the JustFOIA system itself). Do not delete, overwrite, or recycle logs or backups potentially responsive to this request.

Production & delivery preferences (electronic, native, no portal)

Provide records electronically in native format with metadata intact (e.g., PST/MBOX for email; XLSX/CSV for spreadsheets/data; JSON/CSV/XML for exports; MSG/EML with attachments; original images/videos). Do not print electronic records to PDF unless the original is PDF.

Delivery: Please do not use the JustFOIA portal for this request. Send by direct email attachments, or direct, publicly accessible download links (no login or registration). If size is an issue, use a standard file-transfer link accessible without creating an account.

If any portion is withheld or redacted, provide a specific exemption log stating the statutory basis and a brief explanation (RCW 42.56.210(3)).

If you believe any item is not “reasonably locatable,” please describe the systems searched, custodians, date ranges, and search terms used, and identify systems not searched and why.

Repositories and custodians to search (non-exhaustive)

Custodians: Public Records Office; Legal/General Counsel/Risk; IT leadership and admins; Enterprise Apps; Information Security; Infrastructure/Network; Procurement/Purchasing; Finance/AP; Communications; Superintendent’s Office; any project managers, analysts, or staff assigned to PRA or JustFOIA; any contractors/consultants who implemented or support JustFOIA.

Systems: Microsoft 365/Exchange/Outlook, Teams, SharePoint, OneDrive; Slack (if used); ticketing/ITSM (e.g., ServiceNow, Freshservice, Zendesk, Jira, Spiceworks); procurement/ERP/finance/AP; identity/SSO (Azure AD/Entra ID, Okta, ADFS); log management/SIEM; backup/archival; and the JustFOIA production and test/sandbox environments.

Search terms (minimum baseline; add equivalents & abbreviations)

“JustFOIA” OR “Just FOIA” OR “Just-FOIA”

“CivicPlus” OR “Civic Plus”

Contract numbers, RFP/PO numbers related to the platform

“PRA software”, “public records system”, “records portal”, “request portal”, “redaction tool”

“implementation”, “migration”, “configuration”, “SSO”, “integration”, “API”, “export”, “retention”, “audit log”, “training”, “UAT”, “go-live”, “outage”, “incident”, “breach”, “security”, “SOC 2”

Requested record categories (A–Z)

Please produce all records and writings responsive to each category. If a record falls into multiple categories, one copy is sufficient.

A. Procurement & selection
Needs assessments, market scans, vendor demos, ROI/benefit analyses, budget justifications, sole-source justifications, RFIs/RFQs/RFPs, Q&A, vendor responses, evaluation criteria, scoring sheets, selection memos, recommendation approvals, board materials, and decision emails.

B. Contracts & legal
All agreements with CivicPlus/JustFOIA and related vendors (master agreements, order forms, statements of work, addenda, DPAs/BAAs, SLAs/uptime, support/maintenance, data residency, subcontractors), standard terms, non-disclosure agreements, termination/exit clauses, and notices of assignment or subcontracting.

C. Financials
Funding approvals, POs, requisitions, quotes, pricing sheets, invoices, credit memos, payment records, account statements, and any grant paperwork tied to the purchase.

D. Implementation project
Project charters, plans, schedules, task trackers, risk/issue logs, change requests, cut-over plans, acceptance criteria, UAT scripts/results, go-live approvals, post-implementation reviews, and internal status reports.

E. Architecture & integrations
System/network diagrams; integration designs with email, M365/SharePoint/OneDrive, imaging/scanning, archives, and ticketing; API usage docs; SSO/SAML/OAuth/OpenID configuration guides; data flow maps and data dictionaries.

F. Security & privacy
Security/privacy assessments (DPIA/PIA), vendor questionnaires, risk acceptance memos, encryption/Key management details (as held by LWSD), vulnerability/penetration summaries, SOC 2/ISO certificates in LWSD’s possession, incident/outage/breach notices, and any security advisories received from CivicPlus.

G. Policies & procedures
Current and historical policies/SOPs/workflows for handling PRA requests in JustFOIA (intake, search, review, redaction, exemption application, installment production, appeal/closure), including redaction and exemption templates.

H. Training & user guidance
Training decks, handouts, recordings, internal “how-to” guides, quick-reference materials, and vendor-provided manuals kept by LWSD.

I. Configuration & administration
Tenant/instance settings, retention rules, routing rules/queues, templates, redaction presets, exemption code lists, custom fields, tags, roles/permissions matrices, SSO/IdP mappings, and automation rules (including any scripts).

J. Users & access
User/account lists (names may be redacted as necessary), roles, group assignments, provisioning/deprovisioning records, MFA/SSO enrollment logs, and audit trails of admin actions.

K. Logs (system & audit)
Access logs, authentication logs, admin logs, change/config logs, export/download logs, redaction activity logs, deletion/closure logs, error/outage logs, and any API call logs.

L. Data & schema
Field lists, data models, table layouts, picklist values, and sample exports (with sensitive requester content redacted if necessary) showing how LWSD data is stored.

M. Usage & performance
Reports/dashboards on request volumes, processing times, backlog, installment counts, on-time percentage, appeal/closure stats, and any KPI summaries provided by the system or vendor.

N. Communications with vendor(s)
All emails/chats/letters/meeting notes between LWSD and CivicPlus/JustFOIA (sales, implementation, support, account management, renewals, outages, feature requests, compliance/legal).

O. Internal communications
Emails/chats/notes among LWSD personnel referencing JustFOIA/CivicPlus and the system’s selection, rollout, configuration, operations, outages, performance, redaction/exemptions, retention, or reporting.

P. Support & tickets
IT tickets, vendor cases, bug reports, feature requests, troubleshooting notes, escalation records, and resolutions.

Q. Web & public-facing
Website pages, announcements, instructions to requesters about using/not using the portal, and any accessibility or usability testing results.

R. Retention, backup, & archival
Records describing backups/snapshots, retention/disposition schedules, export procedures, and any migrations into or out of JustFOIA.

S. Migration/transition
Records of data migration from prior systems into JustFOIA, or from JustFOIA to any successor platform, including mapping documents and validation results.

T. Legal holds & litigation
Notices of hold involving JustFOIA data, instructions to staff, and any litigation/appeal materials referencing the system’s records.

U. Accessibility & equity
ADA/Section 508 evaluations, language access accommodations in the system, and related compliance assessments.

V. Third-party notifications
Any notifications to third parties about disclosure of their information from JustFOIA, including templates used.

W. Testing/sandbox
Existence and use of staging/sandbox environments; test plans and test data handling policies.

X. Change management
Change approval records (CAB), release notes maintained by LWSD, version/feature enablement decisions.

Y. Termination/exit
If applicable, records regarding contract non-renewal, termination, or exit planning, including data return/deletion certificates.

Z. Delivery method for this request
Any internal records discussing or directing that JustFOIA should not be used to deliver records for this specific request, and the alternative delivery steps adopted.

RECORDS INSTALLMENTS - ORDER OF PRODUCTION

If production of responsive records will be completed in multiple installments, please begin by producing records in REVERSE CHRONOLOGICAL FORMAT BY DATE. The most recent public records should be produced first and the oldest records produced last by date.

NATIVE ELECTRONIC FORMAT

Please provide all identified public records in their NATIVE electronic format. Please provide all electronic records in the fewest number of individual files as per native format or use free .zip or digital compression in each installment for the fewest number of total records and the most economical calculation of any applicable public records fees.

Third-party portals often require creating an account or logging in, restrict downloads or viewing times, and remove or disable links after a short period of time.

These restrictions unlawfully condition access to public records and are inconsistent with RCW 42.56.080 and RCW 42.56.550.

Because of this, Washington State Law is clear that the use of 3rd party “portals” (Such as GOVQA.com) for  public records requests is optional for the requestor. Respectfully I decline. Please provide all records electronically via direct email attachment to this email address.

Please do not register this requestor for, nor direct this requestor to the use of any 3rd party commercial portal including but not limited to FOIAOnline, GovQA, NextRequest, FOIAExpress, JustFOIA FOIADirect, WebForm, or any other online service other than a direct NO PASSWORD REQUIRED, NO REGISTRATION REQUIRED, internet cloud-based download link, or electronic email.

Do not send any portion of this public records request to any 3rd party for-profit corporation such as GOVQA, a Grannicus Corporation or NEXT-REQUEST.

Do not register this request with any for profit portal or 3rd party organization such as GOVQA, a Grannicus Corporation, or NEXT-REQUEST.

RCW 42.56.080 - Identifiable records—Facilities for copying—Availability of public records.

"...Agencies shall honor requests received in person during an agency's normal office hours, or by mail or email, for identifiable public records unless exempted by provisions of this chapter. No official format is required for making a records request; however, agencies may recommend that requestors submit requests using an agency provided form or web page."

COMMERCIAL PURPOSE DECLARATION

WAC 44-14-03005 RETENTION OF PUBLIC RECORDS

The lawful destruction of public records is governed by retention schedules. The unlawful destruction of public records can be a crime. RCW 40.16.010 and 40.16.020. title: Lake Washington School District - eDISCOVERY Software Purchase, Installation, Configuration, Integration, Administration (08/2025)

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: Lake Washington School District - eDISCOVERY Software Purchase, Installation, Configuration, Integration, Administration (08/2025)
communications.communication:
08-13-2025

via email to PublicRecordsRequest@lwsd.org

Lake Washington School District - eDISCOVERY Software Purchase, Installation, Configuration, Integration, Administration (08/2025)

PUBLIC RECORDS REQUEST RCW 42.56

To whom it may concern,

I request the following identifiable public records to be produced in the following order of production, newest to oldest by year:

Pursuant to Washington’s Public Records Act (PRA), RCW 42.56, I request electronic copies of all records and writings (as those terms are defined in RCW 42.56.010) relating to Lake Washington School District’s purchase, installation, configuration, integration, administration, and use of any and all “eDiscovery” software systems, platforms, or tools — including, but not limited to, products or services from Microsoft (e.g., Microsoft Purview eDiscovery Standard/Premium, Microsoft 365 Advanced eDiscovery), Google Vault, Relativity, Everlaw, Logikcull, Exterro, OpenText/EnCase, Zapproved, Casepoint, Nextpoint, Concordance, Nuix, or any other vendor, open-source, or in-house-developed eDiscovery solution used for searching, reviewing, and/or producing electronically stored information (ESI).

TIMEFRAME

Please search from January 1, 2010 to the present, or the earliest date responsive records exist, whichever is broader.

Definitions, scope, and preservation

“Records” and “writings” include all formats: emails, texts/iMessages, chats (Teams/Slack/Google Chat), letters, notes, photos, spreadsheets, databases, calendars, audio/video, PDFs, logs, dashboards, data exports, screen captures, configuration files, source or script files, API payloads, and associated metadata. See RCW 42.56.010; O’Neill v. City of Shoreline.

Personal accounts/devices used for public business are in scope (texts, emails, etc.). See Nissen v. Pierce County.

Please preserve potentially responsive ESI in all systems, backups, archives, and logs.

Production & delivery preferences (electronic, native, no portal)

Provide records electronically in native format with metadata intact (PST/MBOX for email; XLSX/CSV for spreadsheets/data; MSG/EML for emails; JSON/XML for exports).

Delivery: Send via direct email attachment or direct, public download link — do not require portal login or registration.

Provide an exemption log for any withheld/redacted records (RCW 42.56.210(3)).

Describe search methods if any items are claimed not “reasonably locatable.”

Repositories and custodians to search (non-exhaustive):

Custodians: Public Records Office, Legal Counsel/Risk Management, IT leadership/admins, Security, Infrastructure, Enterprise Apps, Procurement, Finance/AP, HR (if involved in investigations), any project managers, analysts, or contractors for eDiscovery implementation/support.

Systems: Microsoft 365/Exchange/Teams/SharePoint/OneDrive, Google Workspace, email archives/journaling, log management/SIEM, ticketing/ITSM, file servers, imaging/scanning, cloud storage, prior eDiscovery tools.

Search terms (minimum baseline):

“eDiscovery”, “e-discovery”, “ediscovery”

“Microsoft Purview”, “Advanced eDiscovery”, “Content Search”, “Core eDiscovery”, “Security & Compliance Center”

“Google Vault”

“Relativity”, “Everlaw”, “Logikcull”, “Exterro”, “Nuix”, “Casepoint”, “Zapproved”, “OpenText”, “EnCase”, “Nextpoint”, “Concordance”, “Clearwell”

“litigation hold”, “legal hold”, “custodian search”, “document review”, “ESI processing”, “PST export”

Contract/RFP/PO numbers related to any eDiscovery platform

Requested record categories (A–Z):

A. Procurement & selection – Needs assessments, vendor comparisons, demos, RFIs/RFQs/RFPs, Q&A, evaluation scores, board approval, and decision memos.

B. Contracts & legal – All agreements with eDiscovery vendors, SLAs, DPAs, security addenda, subcontractor notices.

C. Financials – POs, invoices, quotes, pricing, funding approvals, payment records.

D. Implementation project – Plans, schedules, milestones, UAT, acceptance docs, post-implementation reviews.

E. Architecture & integrations – Network/system diagrams, email archive connections, integrations with M365, Google Workspace, file servers, ticketing, legal case management.

F. Security & privacy – Risk assessments, vendor security questionnaires, incident/breach notices, SOC 2/ISO reports in LWSD possession.

G. Policies & procedures – SOPs for search, review, tagging, redaction, production; chain-of-custody processes; export/transfer guidelines.

H. Training & user guidance – Training decks, manuals, quick-reference sheets, internal guides.

I. Configuration & administration – Retention rules, search indexes, roles/permissions, tagging schemas, redaction presets, data source lists.

J. Users & access – User lists, role assignments, provisioning/deprovisioning logs, MFA/SSO logs.

K. Logs (system & audit) – Search logs, export logs, login/access logs, chain-of-custody logs, error/outage logs.

L. Data & schema – Field lists, index structures, data models, sample exports (redacted if necessary).

M. Usage & performance – Reports/dashboards on searches, review volumes, case counts, processing times.

N. Communications with vendor(s) – All correspondence about procurement, implementation, support, upgrades, feature requests, outages.

O. Internal communications – Staff discussions on system use, search strategies, redaction policies, production decisions.

P. Support & tickets – Vendor and internal support tickets, bug reports, feature requests.

Q. Web & public-facing – Any public instructions or disclosures about LWSD’s eDiscovery tools.

R. Retention, backup, & archival – Backup policies, archival schedules, export procedures, migration plans.

S. Migration/transition – Moves from prior systems to current or future eDiscovery platforms.

T. Legal holds & litigation – Hold notices, custodian lists, compliance tracking, release notices.

U. Accessibility & equity – ADA/Section 508 compliance for review portals.

V. Third-party notifications – Notices to data subjects or third parties about disclosures.

W. Testing/sandbox – Test environment records, handling of test data.

X. Change management – CAB approvals, release notes, change logs.

Y. Termination/exit – Data export, return/destruction certificates, exit strategy records.

Z. Delivery method for this request – Internal decisions about how eDiscovery records are produced in response to PRA requests.

RECORDS INSTALLMENTS - ORDER OF PRODUCTION

If production of responsive records will be completed in multiple installments, please begin by producing records in REVERSE CHRONOLOGICAL FORMAT BY DATE. The most recent public records should be produced first and the oldest records produced last by date.

NATIVE ELECTRONIC FORMAT

Please provide all identified public records in their NATIVE electronic format. Please provide all electronic records in the fewest number of individual files as per native format or use free .zip or digital compression in each installment for the fewest number of total records and the most economical calculation of any applicable public records fees.

USE OF PORTAL NOT MANDATORY - DIRECTING REQUESTORS TO THIRD-PARTY LINKS VIOLATES ACCESS RIGHTS

Third-party portals often require creating an account or logging in, restrict downloads or viewing times, and remove or disable links after a short period of time.

These restrictions unlawfully condition access to public records and are inconsistent with RCW 42.56.080 and RCW 42.56.550.

Because of this, Washington State Law is clear that the use of 3rd party “portals” (Such as GOVQA.com) for  public records requests is optional for the requestor. Respectfully I decline. Please provide all records electronically via direct email attachment to this email address.

Please do not register this requestor for, nor direct this requestor to the use of any 3rd party commercial portal including but not limited to FOIAOnline, GovQA, NextRequest, FOIAExpress, JustFOIA FOIADirect, WebForm, or any other online service other than a direct NO PASSWORD REQUIRED, NO REGISTRATION REQUIRED, internet cloud-based download link, or electronic email.

Do not send any portion of this public records request to any 3rd party for-profit corporation such as GOVQA, a Grannicus Corporation or NEXT-REQUEST.

Do not register this request with any for profit portal or 3rd party organization such as GOVQA, a Grannicus Corporation, or NEXT-REQUEST.

PUBLIC RECORDS REQUESTS SUBMITTED VIA EMAIL

RCW 42.56.080 - Identifiable records—Facilities for copying—Availability of public records.

"...Agencies shall honor requests received in person during an agency's normal office hours, or by mail or email, for identifiable public records unless exempted by provisions of this chapter. No official format is required for making a records request; however, agencies may recommend that requestors submit requests using an agency provided form or web page."

This public records request is being made via email. This public records request will be honored and fulfilled by your agency via email as requested or relief will be sought per statute.

FEES

In the event that there are fees, please inform us of the total charges in advance of fulfilling the request in strict compliance with all provisions of the Washington State Public Records Act.

EXEMPTION LOGS

Please ensure all redactions or exemptions claimed by your agency in the production of responsive records are accompanied by a complete and detailed exemption log noting the valid legal reason for each exemption at each redaction location in the record produced, as well as the specific number of pages if any that your agency redacts or withholds in their entirety. Each redaction should be noted by footnote or by a clear reference to the specific justification for that redaction, and only the minimal exempt portion of any record may be withheld.

COMMERCIAL PURPOSE DECLARATION

The Washington State Public Records Act prohibits the disclosure of “lists of individuals” for a commercial purpose (RCW 42.56.070(8)). I declare this public records request is not being made for any commercial purpose whatsoever. Also, this public records request is not being made for a "list of individuals." This declaration satisfies all requirements of RCW 42.56 regarding prohibitions on lists and commercial purposes. No additional commercial purpose declaration will be completed for this public records request.

PRESERVATION OF PUBLIC RECORDS *** ANTICIPATE LITIGATION ***

WAC 44-14-03005 RETENTION OF PUBLIC RECORDS

The lawful destruction of public records is governed by retention schedules. The unlawful destruction of public records can be a crime. RCW 40.16.010 and 40.16.020. An agency is prohibited from destroying a public record, even if it is about to be lawfully destroyed under a retention schedule, if a public records request has been made for that record. RCW 42.56.100. Additional retention requirements might apply if the records may be relevant to actual or anticipated litigation. The agency is required to retain the record until the record request has been resolved.

Note: An agency can be found to violate the Public Records Act and be subject to the attorneys' fees and penalty provision if it prematurely destroys a requested record after a request is made. See Yacobellis v. City of Bellingham, 55 Wn. App. 706, 780 P.2d 272 (1989). However, it is not a violation of the Public Records Act if a record is destroyed prior to an agency's receipt of a public records request for that record. Bldg. Indus. Ass'n of Wash. v. McCarthy, 152 Wn. App. 720, 218 P.3d 196 (2009); West v. Dep't of Nat. Res., 163 Wn. App. 238, 258 P.3d 78 (2011). The Public Records Act (chapter 42.56 RCW) and the records retention statutes (chapter 40.14 RCW) are two different laws.

COMMUNICATION VIA EMAIL

Please send all requests for clarification, status updates, and production of responsive electronic documents via direct email reply.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. We look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Good Luck.

August 13, 2025

Office of Superintendent of Public Instruction
Attn: Public Records Office

Via email:  PublicRecordsRequest@k12.wa.us

Public Records Act Request  

Dear Public Records Officer:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, RCW 42.56, I request copies (in native or PDF format) of all public records held by your agency relating to the following Lake Washington School District employee:

Barbara C. Posthumus, Associate Superintendent - Lake Washington School District

Barbara C. Posthumus
7009 150th Ave NE, Redmond, WA 98052
DOB: July 1, 1968
(425) 702-3349
(702) 408-6457
(360) 500-3470

Responsive public records include, but are not limited to, the following categories:

1. Certification & Licensing Records

(Required disclosure: RCW 42.56.070(1); *Belenski v. Jefferson County*, 186 Wn.2d 452 (2016))

* Certificate type(s), endorsement(s), and specialties
* Issuance and expiration dates
* Renewal history
* Status (active, expired, revoked, suspended)
* Revocation/suspension orders or findings
* Professional education permits
* OSPI credential verification and related records

 2. Employment History & Job-Related Information

(Required disclosure: RCW 42.56.070(1); *Predisik v. Spokane School Dist. No. 81*, 182 Wn.2d 896 (2015))

* Job titles and positions held
* Dates of employment and assignment locations
* Salary placement and pay history
* Work-related training records, workshops, and continuing education completed
* Performance evaluations (with student identifiers redacted per RCW 42.56.230 & FERPA)

3. Disciplinary Records

(Required disclosure: RCW 42.56.070(1); *Spokane Police Guild v. Liquor Control Bd.*, 112 Wn. App. 467 (2002))

* Final disciplinary decisions and findings
* Written reprimands, letters of censure, and settlement agreements
* Revocation/suspension letters from OSPI’s Office of Professional Practices
* Findings of unprofessional conduct

4. Application & Appointment Records

* Completed certification and endorsement applications
* Renewal forms and supporting documentation
* Hiring applications, resumes, and cover letters (with personal contact info redacted per RCW 42.56.250(1))
* Interview scoring or selection records (post-hiring)

 5. Sexual Misconduct Disclosure Release Forms

(Required under RCW 28A.400.303)

* Completed forms, with only the following redactions permitted:
  * SSNs, DOBs, driver’s license numbers (RCW 42.56.230(5) & RCW 42.56.250(8))
  * Personal contact info of references (RCW 42.56.250(1))

 6. Complaints & Investigations

* Complaints, investigation reports, and witness statements (with student names redacted per FERPA and RCW 42.56.230)
* Correspondence related to investigations


7. Training & Professional Development

* Clock hour records and transcripts of district/OSPI-sponsored training
* Specialty program certifications (e.g., safety, bilingual, special education endorsements)


8. Financial & Contractual Records

* Employment contracts, supplemental pay agreements, and stipend contracts
* Expense reimbursements and travel claims related to official duties

RECORDS INSTALLMENTS - ORDER OF PRODUCTION

If production of responsive records will be completed in multiple installments, please begin by producing records in REVERSE CHRONOLOGICAL FORMAT BY DATE. The most recent public records should be produced first and the oldest records produced last by date.

NATIVE ELECTRONIC FORMAT

Please provide all identified public records in their NATIVE electronic format. Please provide all electronic records in the fewest number of individual files as per native format or use free .zip or digital compression in each installment for the fewest number of total records and the most economical calculation of any applicable public records fees.

USE OF PORTAL NOT MANDATORY - DIRECTING REQUESTORS TO THIRD-PARTY LINKS VIOLATES ACCESS RIGHTS

Third-party portals often require creating an account or logging in, restrict downloads or viewing times, and remove or disable links after a short period of time.

These restrictions unlawfully condition access to public records and are inconsistent with RCW 42.56.080 and RCW 42.56.550.

Because of this, Washington State Law is clear that the use of 3rd party “portals” (Such as GOVQA.com) for  public records requests is optional for the requestor. Respectfully I decline. Please provide all records electronically via direct email attachment to this email address.

Please do not register this requestor for, nor direct this requestor to the use of any 3rd party commercial portal including but not limited to FOIAOnline, GovQA, NextRequest, FOIAExpress, JustFOIA FOIADirect, WebForm, or any other online service other than a direct NO PASSWORD REQUIRED, NO REGISTRATION REQUIRED, internet cloud-based download link, or electronic email.

Do not send any portion of this public records request to any 3rd party for-profit corporation such as GOVQA, a Grannicus Corporation or NEXT-REQUEST.

Do not register this request with any for profit portal or 3rd party organization such as GOVQA, a Grannicus Corporation, or NEXT-REQUEST.


PUBLIC RECORDS REQUESTS SUBMITTED VIA EMAIL

RCW 42.56.080 - Identifiable records—Facilities for copying—Availability of public records.

"...Agencies shall honor requests received in person during an agency's normal office hours, or by mail or email, for identifiable public records unless exempted by provisions of this chapter. No official format is required for making a records request; however, agencies may recommend that requestors submit requests using an agency provided form or web page."

This public records request is being made via email. This public records request will be honored and fulfilled by your agency via email as requested or relief will be sought per statute.

FEES

In the event that there are fees, please inform us of the total charges in advance of fulfilling the request in strict compliance with all provisions of the Washington State Public Records Act.

EXEMPTION LOGS

Please ensure all redactions or exemptions claimed by your agency in the production of responsive records are accompanied by a complete and detailed exemption log noting the valid legal reason for each exemption at each redaction location in the record produced, as well as the specific number of pages if any that your agency redacts or withholds in their entirety. Each redaction should be noted by footnote or by a clear reference to the specific justification for that redaction, and only the minimal exempt portion of any record may be withheld.

COMMERCIAL PURPOSE DECLARATION

The Washington State Public Records Act prohibits the disclosure of “lists of individuals” for a commercial purpose (RCW 42.56.070(8)). I declare this public records request is not being made for any commercial purpose whatsoever. Also, this public records request is not being made for a "list of individuals." This declaration satisfies all requirements of RCW 42.56 regarding prohibitions on lists and commercial purposes. No additional commercial purpose declaration will be completed for this public records request.

PRESERVATION OF PUBLIC RECORDS *** ANTICIPATE LITIGATION ***

WAC 44-14-03005 RETENTION OF PUBLIC RECORDS

The lawful destruction of public records is governed by retention schedules. The unlawful destruction of public records can be a crime. RCW 40.16.010 and 40.16.020. An agency is prohibited from destroying a public record, even if it is about to be lawfully destroyed under a retention schedule, if a public records request has been made for that record. RCW 42.56.100. Additional retention requirements might apply if the records may be relevant to actual or anticipated litigation. The agency is required to retain the record until the record request has been resolved.

Note: An agency can be found to violate the Public Records Act and be subject to the attorneys' fees and penalty provision if it prematurely destroys a requested record after a request is made. See Yacobellis v. City of Bellingham, 55 Wn. App. 706, 780 P.2d 272 (1989). However, it is not a violation of the Public Records Act if a record is destroyed prior to an agency's receipt of a public records request for that record. Bldg. Indus. Ass'n of Wash. v. McCarthy, 152 Wn. App. 720, 218 P.3d 196 (2009); West v. Dep't of Nat. Res., 163 Wn. App. 238, 258 P.3d 78 (2011). The Public Records Act (chapter 42.56 RCW) and the records retention statutes (chapter 40.14 RCW) are two different laws.

COMMUNICATION VIA EMAIL

Please send all requests for clarification, status updates, and production of responsive electronic documents via direct email reply.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. We look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Good Luck.

"...Agencies shall honor requests received in person during an agency's normal office hours, or by mail or email, for identifiable public records unless exempted by provisions of this chapter. No official format is required for making a records request; however, agencies may recommend that requestors submit requests using an agency provided form or web page."

This public records request is being made via email. This public records request will be honored and fulfilled by your agency via email as requested or relief will be sought per statute.

FEES

In the event that there are fees, please inform us of the total charges in advance of fulfilling the request in strict compliance with all provisions of the Washington State Public Records Act.

EXEMPTION LOGS

Please ensure all redactions or exemptions claimed by your agency in the production of responsive records are accompanied by a complete and detailed exemption log noting the valid legal reason for each exemption at each redaction location in the record produced, as well as the specific number of pages if any that your agency redacts or withholds in their entirety. Each redaction should be noted by footnote or by a clear reference to the specific justification for that redaction, and only the minimal exempt portion of any record may be withheld.

COMMERCIAL PURPOSE DECLARATION

The Washington State Public Records Act prohibits the disclosure of “lists of individuals” for a commercial purpose (RCW 42.56.070(8)). I declare this public records request is not being made for any commercial purpose whatsoever. Also, this public records request is not being made for a "list of individuals." This declaration satisfies all requirements of RCW 42.56 regarding prohibitions on lists and commercial purposes. No additional commercial purpose declaration will be completed for this public records request.

PRESERVATION OF PUBLIC RECORDS *** ANTICIPATE LITIGATION ***

WAC 44-14-03005 RETENTION OF PUBLIC RECORDS

The lawful destruction of public records is governed by retention schedules. The unlawful destruction of public records can be a crime. RCW 40.16.010 and 40.16.020. An agency is prohibited from destroying a public record, even if it is about to be lawfully destroyed under a retention schedule, if a public records request has been made for that record. RCW 42.56.100. Additional retention requirements might apply if the records may be relevant to actual or anticipated litigation. The agency is required to retain the record until the record request has been resolved.

Note: An agency can be found to violate the Public Records Act and be subject to the attorneys' fees and penalty provision if it prematurely destroys a requested record after a request is made. See Yacobellis v. City of Bellingham, 55 Wn. App. 706, 780 P.2d 272 (1989). However, it is not a violation of the Public Records Act if a record is destroyed prior to an agency's receipt of a public records request for that record. Bldg. Indus. Ass'n of Wash. v. McCarthy, 152 Wn. App. 720, 218 P.3d 196 (2009); West v. Dep't of Nat. Res., 163 Wn. App. 238, 258 P.3d 78 (2011). The Public Records Act (chapter 42.56 RCW) and the records retention statutes (chapter 40.14 RCW) are two different laws.

COMMUNICATION VIA EMAIL

Please send all requests for clarification, status updates, and production of responsive electronic documents via direct email reply.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. We look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Good Luck.

title: Aracelys Terrero Mota

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Aracelys Terrero Mota
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

According to documents obtained from previous records requests, two CBP agents (Morales and Muñiz) in Puerto Rico exchanged calls with municipal police officer Jose F. Toro Segarra on or around May 25, 2025 concerning Dominican migrant Aracelys Terrero Mota. 

A copy of this record has been submitted alongside this records request.

Therefore, I request the following records:

1)  All instructional materials, presentations and presentation materials (including recorded video and audio, PowerPoint files, prepared remarks, and slides formats), and other guidance relating to communications between CBP and the Cabo Rojo municipal police about Aracelys Terrero Mota. This includes A) any notes taken during meetings that discussed communications with municipal police, Aracelys Terrero Mota, and/or her arrest by CBP, B) any explanations (whether internally or externally generated) about communications with municipal police, Aracelys Terrero Mota, and/or her arrest by CBP, and C) any other document that has been used to help explain communications with municipal police, Aracelys Terrero Mota, and/or her arrest by CBP, including internal documentation, public relations materials, and executive summaries.

2) Any digital communications (including but not limited to emails and text messages), as well as documents (including but not limited to PDF, word processing, excel, and slide documents) that mention Aracelys Terrero Mota or her arrest on or around May 27, 2025 exchanged with the Cabo Rojo municipal police. 

3) Any case reports or after action reports mentioning Aracelys Terrero Mota.

To aid in your search, potentially responsive documents will likely exclusively be found with the offices of CBP agents working in Puerto Rico within the Ramey Sector. 

To aid in your search, please use the following keywords:
"Aracelys" 
"Terrero-Mota"
"Aracelys Terrero Mota"
"Cabo Rojo"
"Toro Segarra"
"Martinez Acosta"
"Santiago"
"Muñiz"
"Morales"

This records request is for all records produced between May 24, 2025 and August 1, 2025. In the case there are multiple records, please send them to me on a rolling basis.

This request is not being made for commercial purposes. Any documents produced from this request will be used in the course of reporting about immigration for Heavy Weather, an independent newsletter about Puerto Rico. www.heavyweather.media.com

I am formally requesting expedited processing of my FOIA request submitted to your agency. My request seeks records related to Operation Cupid's Nest, an immigration enforcement operation taking place in at least one airport in the United States. The information is critical to inform the public about ongoing immigration enforcement actions currently taking place across the United States that may impact air travel at a time when both immigration and transportation are issues that are constantly in the news media every day. I believe this request qualifies for expedited processing under criteria outlines in 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(E) and the implementing regulations of your agency.

Justification for Expedited Processing

1) Compelling Need for Urgency: There is a compelling need for the timely release of the requested records due to undocumented immigration and air travel being matters of significant public interest at this time. The information sought is critical to informing the public about how federal agencies deal with undocumented immigration and detained undocumented immigrants, as well as how these operations are taking place across airports in the United States.

2) Public Interest: The requested records pertain to a matter of widespread and exceptional media interest and concern to the general public. Specifically, records relate to the arrest of undocumented migrants, an issue that has been the subject of extensive media coverage and public debate. Expedited processing is necessary to ensure that the public is informed about this issue in a timely manner.

3) Risk of Irreparable Harm: Delay in processing this request could result in irreparable harm. For example, the requested records are needed to address the ongoing issue of undocumented immigration that has significant consequences for public safety, civil liberties, or government accountability, especially since it is related to how federal agencies are responding to this issue. Without expedited processing, the value of the requested information may be significantly diminished.

4) Statutory and Regulatory Criteria: My request meets the statutory and regulatory criteria for expedited processing. My request is a matter of widespread and exceptional media interest in which there exists an urgency to inform the public about actual or alleged federal government activity. My request has a compelling need for the information to address a pressing issue of public concern.

I respectfully urge your agency to grant expedited processing for this FOIA request to ensure timely access to the requested records. I appreciate your prompt attention to this matter and your commitment to upholding the principles of transparency and accountability under the FOIA. Thank you for your consideration. Please do not hesitate to contact me at carlosBP@protonmail.com if you require additional information or clarification regarding this request.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Carlos Berríos Polanco

title: ICE video footage

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: ICE video footage
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

o Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

The public should have access to any unedited audio or visual recordings of ICE's enforcement operations in California between January 6, 2025 to the present. Since at least 2010, ICE has created and made public hundreds of videos of various internal agency operations, including arrests, detention, and removals. Recently ICE and accompanying agencies have released videos of operations in Los Angeles that have included a raid on MacArthur Park. Videographers accompanied the agency, and the content was shared across multiple platforms. Other operations have been videotaped and shared online by the agency. On one publicly available website, ICE videographers have uploaded videos of agency actions. Given ICE's widespread practice of recording its operations, additional and unedited recordings of ICE operations in California likely exist but have not been made public. These videos contain important information about the tactics used when arresting noncitizens and whether ICE officers are acting in a manner consistent with ICE's own protocols and state and federal due process laws. Because these video and audio records contain information about a critical government function on a matter of significant public interest and concern, FOIA mandates their disclosure.

Request:

1. Visual recordings taken by the department or contracted videographers of ICE operations to share on social media, advertising, and with news outlets, including arrests, detention, and removals, in Los Angeles between January 6, 2025, to the present. 

The Requestors:

Joey Scott and Jeremy Lindenfield are both journalists who work in news gathering, including written and visual reporting. Joey Scott is a freelance investigative journalist in Los Angeles. Jeremy Lindenfield is a journalist for Capital and Main news.

Fee Waiver

The Requestor seeks a full fee waiver on the grounds that disclosure of the requested records is in the public interest and is "likely to contribute significantly to public understanding of operations or activities of the government and is not primarily in the commercial interest of the requestor." 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(iii). As set forth above, this request aims to further public understanding of ICE programs and practices that directly affect untold numbers of noncitizens as well as members of the public captured in video recordings of ICE enforcement actions. These policies and practices are of interest to the general public.

The public interest fee waiver provision "is to be liberally construed in favor of waivers for noncommercial requesters." McClellan Ecologic Seepage Situation v. Carlucci, 835 F.2d 1282, 1284 (9th Cir. 1987). The relevant question is whether the requested information is likely to contribute significantly to public understanding of the operations or activities of the government, good or bad. See judicial Watch, Inc. v. Rossotti, 326 F.3d 1309, 1314 (D.C. Cir. 2003). Disclosure of the information and report sought is in the public interest and will contribute significantly to the public's understanding of the treatment of immigrants during enforcement actions. The requested records also relate directly to government operations, including the use and storage of video files that potentially implicate fundamental rights and freedoms, including the right to privacy. The requested records also relate to the relationship between the federal government and private, for-profit contracted entities.

The records are not sought for commercial use, and the Requestor plans to disseminate the information disclosed through print and other media to the public at no cost. As demonstrated above, the Requestor has both the intent and ability to convey any information obtained through this request to the public and is therefore entitled to a full fee waiver under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(iii).

Should the request for a full fee waiver be denied, Requestor also seeks a limitation of processing fees pursuant to 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(ii)(II) ("fees shall be limited to reasonable standard charges for document duplication when records are not sought for commercial use and the request is made by ... educational or noncommercial scientific institution ... or a representative of the news media") and 6 C.F.R. § 5.11(d)(1) (search fees shall not be charged to "representatives of the news media"). Requestor is a non-profit organization that intends to disseminate the information gathered by this request to the public at no cost, including through the Requestor's website and social media. The Requestor may publish a news story or other publication on the government's treatment of immigrants based on information gathered through this FOIA.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Joey Scott

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

communications.subject: Wisconsin Open Records Act Request: Lake Geneva Wisconsin and White River Holdings
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Wisconsin Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Pursuant to the Wisconsin Public Records Law (Wis. Stat. §§ 19.31–19.39), I am requesting copies of all emails, notes, and correspondence between the City of Lake Geneva (including staff, elected officials, and any agents or representatives of the City) and White River Holdings LLC concerning the deed restriction on the following properties:

Tax Key No. ZOP 0001

Tax Key No. ZYUP 00131

Tax Key No. ZYUP 00001A

Tax Key No. ZYUP 00001C

Parcel .3 — Tax Key No. ZYUP 00153

This request specifically includes, but is not limited to, communications relating to the Special Warranty Deed dated December 9, 2022 and any subsequent discussions, negotiations, or modifications related to that deed restriction.

If any records are withheld in whole or in part, please provide the specific statutory exemption relied upon and describe the nature of the records being withheld.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Gary Milliette

title: City of Lake Geneva Wisconsin owned property appraisals

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Wisconsin Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Stat. §§ 19.31–19.39), I am requesting copies of any and all appraisals, valuations, or opinions of value prepared for or provided to the City of Lake Geneva for the city-owned property known as Hillmoor, which abuts Highway 50 in Lake Geneva, Wisconsin.

This request includes, but is not limited to, all formal written appraisals, market analyses, broker price opinions, or any other valuation documents in the City’s possession, whether prepared internally or by outside parties, regardless of date.

title: DEF CON 33 Arrest

communications.subject: Nevada Public Records Act Request: DEF CON 33 Arrest
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Nevada Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

DEF CON 33 was a cybersecurity conference held in Las Vegas on August 7-10th of 2025. I am seeking arrest records relating to this conference. This may involve one case, or multiple. I am not seeking BWC footage. 

Search Criteria: 
A) A list of LVMPD calls to the Las Vegas Convention Center between August 7th and August 10th including date, time, case/call number, and call type/reason. 
B) Case information for an incident at / near the Venetian Hotel involving the confiscation of Flipper Zero devices and four individuals being detained or arrested. DEF CON noted that the individuals may have been DEF CON vendors. To aid in your search, one of the detained/arrested individuals may have the name Fletcher Heisler, there may have been four individuals detained/arrested, and that LVMPD interacted with Venetian Hotel Security prior to the incident. I hope this helps to locate the case. 

I am seeking the following documents:
1) Case numbers associated with these arrests 
2) Police reports, ICRs, investigation supplements, statements and transcripts of interviews, and case notes from these arrests

Please redact arrested party's personal information such as date-of-birth, phone number, home address, driver's license numbers, etc. - I am only seeking information on the context of the arrests, not information on the arrested parties.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Abe Segal

communications.subject: Public Record Request Submitted for Public Record Request - Abe Segal
communications.communication:
Hello Abe Segal,

Public Record Request Title


Public Record Request - Abe Segal  


Public Record Request #


NPR2025-0081688 


Name of Requestor


Abe Segal 


Status


Submitted 


Request Submitted Date


8/12/2025 5:00 PM 






Your Public Record Service Request has been successfully submitted. You will be notified by email if more information or payment is required and when your request is completed. The Las Vegas Metropolitan Police Department - Public Records Unit hours of operation are 8 a.m. to 5 p.m., Monday through Friday, excluding holidays, Juneteenth, Nevada Day, the day after Thanksgiving and December 24th.  Any public record requests made outside of normal business hours will be deemed received the next business day. At any time, you may monitor the status of your request by logging into your Public Records portal account.

***Please note that holidays that fall on a Saturday or Sunday will be observed the preceding Friday or the following Monday. There are 13 holidays that LVMPD observes throughout the year. Based on this information, adjust your request accordingly.

communications.subject: Response to Public Records Request – DEF CON 33 Related Records
communications.communication:
Dear Abe Segal,

This email is in response to your Nevada Public Records Act request regarding incidents related to DEF CON 33, held August 7–10, 2025, in Las Vegas. Your request has been reviewed in two parts:

Part A – Calls for Service (Las Vegas Convention Center)
To obtain a list of calls for service—including 911 Calls for Service, Communications Record Reports, or Phone and Radio Search & Reproduction—you will need to contact our Communications Research Office.

Requests may be submitted:

  *   In person at LVMPD Headquarters or any LVMPD substation, or
  *   Through the Communications Bureau Records Online Portal

  *   Public Records | Las Vegas Metropolitan Police Department<https://www.lvmpd.com/i-want-to/file/public-records>

For assistance, please contact the Communications Research Office directly at (702) 828-3871.

Once you have obtained event numbers from the Communications Research Office, you may submit a follow-up public records request with those specific event numbers, and we will be happy to assist in retrieving any related reports or materials that are eligible for release.

Part B – Incident Involving Detention/Arrests at or Near the Venetian Hotel
Your request appears to be non-specific and overbroad, as it does not identify a particular record or case. Under Nevada law and relevant legal guidance, a valid public records request must reasonably describe an identifiable public record.

Courts have held that public agencies are required to disclose only “identifiable governmental records,” not broad or vague requests for general information to be analyzed or compiled by the agency. See:

  *   Hodai v. City of Tucson & Tucson Police Dep’t, 2014 Ariz. Super. LEXIS 2158, *18 (2014)
  *   MAG Entertainment, LLC v. Division of Alcohol Beverages Control, 868 A.2d 1067, 1076 (N.J. App. Div. 2005)
  *   Capitol Information Association v. Ann Arbor Police, 360 N.W.2d 262, 263 (1985)
  *   See also NAC 239.863(1)(c) (requiring sufficient description to identify a record)

At this time, the Public Records Unit is unable to identify a specific record based on the information provided.
If you are able to provide additional details—such as a case number, event number,  exact date/time, or the full names of involved individuals—we will gladly re-review the request.

Please feel free to contact us with any clarification or updates. We're happy to assist further when specific records can be identified.

Respectfully,

Public Records Unit
Las Vegas Metropolitan Police Department
400-A South Martin L. King Boulevard, Las Vegas, Nevada 89106

title: FOIA Request – Chicago 911 Call Data (Jan. 1, 2022 – Present) (Chicago Police Department)

communications.subject: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: FOIA Request – Chicago 911 Call Data (Jan. 1, 2022 – Present) (Chicago Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request the following records:

Copies of Chicago’s 911 call records from January 1, 2022 through the most recent date available at the time this request is processed.

For each call, please include:
- The most detailed location information available (preferably exact address and GPS coordinates)
- Police district, ward, and beat/precinct
- Date and time of the call
- Priority level
- Call type/category/classification
- Whether the call was behavioral health–related
- Any additional metadata maintained for each call
- Any data dictionaries, codebooks, or similar documentation needed to interpret the records


If the records exist in a database or other structured format (e.g., geoJSON, CSV, Excel, GIS shapefile), please provide them in that format. If parts of the data are exempt from disclosure, release all non-exempt portions.

Clarifications: 
- If the data is stored in a CAD (Computer-Aided Dispatch) or RMS (Records Management System), please export all available fields, including field names, even if they are not part of regularly published reports.
- If any requested detail is not recorded for all calls, provide it where it exists.
- If there is an official dataset name for this information, providing that dataset is acceptable as long as it includes all requested fields.
- If the dataset is updated daily, please run the export on the date the request is fulfilled.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jenny Wadhwa

communications.subject: Your FOIA Request 2025-USMCFOIA-006568
communications.communication:
Good Morning Mr. Free, 

This is to acknowledge the receipt of your request and to let you know that I am the analyst assigned for processing. 

Please be aware that, whenever a FOIA requester has not received a determination within 20 working days from the date a request is perfected, they are entitled to challenge the delay.  To do this, you may submit an appeal within the SecureRelease online portal (www.securerelease.us) or by writing to the Department of the Navy, Office of the Judge Advocate General (Code 14), 1322 Patterson Ave SE, Suite 3000, Washington Navy Yard, DC 20374-5066.  If you prefer, you can also submit an appeal via email to Navy-OJAG-C14-FOIA-PA-ADMINAPPEALS@us.navy.mil.  Your appeal, if any, should include a statement indicating why you believe it should be granted.  It must be postmarked or timestamped within 90 calendar days from the date of this letter. 

Requesters also have the right to seek assistance and/or dispute resolution services from the Department of the Navy FOIA Public Liaison, Mr. Christopher Julka, at Christopher.a.julka.civ@us.navy.mil or (703) 697-0031, and may also contact the Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) for assistance and/or dispute resolution at ogis@nara.gov or (877) 684-6448. 

Thank you for your patience as we work to complete the processing of your request.  Hope you have a great day. 

Sincerely, 
Tara M. Walters 

Commandant of the Marine Corps (ARSF) 
Headquarters US Marine Corps 
3000 Marine Corps Pentagon Rm 2B289 
Washington DC 20350-3000

communications.subject: ICE FOIA 2025-ICFO-54152
communications.communication:
08/13/2025 

Joseph  Cox 
MuckRock News, DEPT MR191074 
Boston, Massachusetts 02115 

RE:	ICE FOIA Case Number 2025-ICFO-54152 
 
Dear Requester: 

This acknowledges receipt of your 8/12/2025, Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request to U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), for records pertaining to all 
invoices, purchases orders, contracts, loan agreements, statements of work, procurement documents (but not limited to solicitation documents or notices of proposed contracts, proposed bids, unsolicited proposals, and/or documents justifying contracting without full and open competition) relating to the following specific procurement identifiers: 
70CTD023FR0000053.  Your request was received in this office on 8/12/2025. 

Due to the increasing number of FOIA requests received by this office, we may encounter some delay in processing your request. Per Section 5.5(a) of the DHS FOIA regulations, 6 C.F.R. Part 5, ICE processes FOIA requests according to their order of receipt. Although ICE’s goal is to respond within 20 business days of receipt of your request, the FOIA does permit a 10-day extension of this time period. As your request seeks numerous documents that will necessitate a thorough and wide-ranging search, ICE will invoke a 10-day extension for your request, as allowed by Title 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(B). If you’re able to narrow the scope of your request please contact our office. Narrowing the scope may speed up the search process. We will make every effort to comply with your request in a timely manner. 

Provisions of the FOIA allow us to recover part of the cost of complying with your request.  We shall charge you for records in accordance with the DHS Interim FOIA regulations, as they apply to media requesters.  As a media requester, you will be charged 10 cents per page for duplication; the first 100 pages are free.  We will construe the submission of your request as an agreement to pay up to $25.00. You will be contacted before any further fees are accrued. 

We have queried the appropriate program offices within ICE for responsive records. If any responsive records are located, they will be reviewed for determination of releasability. Please be assured that one of the processors in our office will respond to your request as expeditiously as possible. We appreciate your patience as we proceed with your request. 

If you have any questions, please contact FOIA Public Liaison, Daniel Edgington at 500 12th Street, SW, Washington DC 20536 or (866) 633-1182. Additionally, you have a right to seek dispute resolution services from the Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) which mediates disputes between FOIA requesters and Federal agencies as a non-exclusive alternative to litigation.  If you are requesting access to your own records (which is considered a Privacy Act request), you should know that OGIS does not have the authority to handle requests made under the Privacy Act of 1974.  You may contact OGIS as follows:  Office of Government Information Services, National Archives and Records Administration, 8601 Adelphi Road-OGIS, College Park, Maryland 20740-6001, e-mail at ogis@nara.gov; telephone at 202-741-5770; toll free at 1-877-684-6448. 

Your request has been assigned reference number 2025-ICFO-54152. Please use this number in future correspondence. 

Sincerely, 

ICE FOIA Office 
Immigration and Customs Enforcement 
Freedom of Information Act Office 
500 12th Street, S.W., Stop 5009 
Washington, D.C. 20536-5009
